>From: "Chad Bohannan" <chad@...>
>
>would this noisy node be garenteed to be evolved out? It seems like a
>really promising idea to 'shakedown' the evolutionary process, but what
>if the network comes to depend on that noise to consistantly 'shake out'
>a solution, instead evolving weights down to zero out the influence?

Would it be guaranteed to evolve out?  No...if the presence of the noise 
gives it an advantage, then it will remain.  What is most likely to happens 
is:  during the early phases, before it has evolved a solution, the presence 
of the noise will be neither helpful nor hurtful, so it will persist.  As it 
begins to find a solution, *if* that solution is robust with respect to the 
noise, then the noise will continue to persist.  If it is a solution that 
benefits from less noise, the noise will be dampened over time by evolved 
reduction in weights to the random input node.  I doubt that it would ever 
evolve to zero, simply by virtue of the evolution process.  But its presence 
would apply significant pressure to the rest of the network to be robust and 
adaptable.

And what if the network does come to depend on that noise?  Read up on 
Stephen Thaler and his Creativity Machine.  
http://www.imagination-engines.com/thaler.htm

-- John
